notes.note: Vertical Tabs: You can now keep more — or fewer — pinned tabs in view for quicker access to important windows. Just drag the divider to resize your pinned tabs section.

Custom Search Engines: Firefox now supports adding even more search engines. To add a custom engine, right-click a search field of a supported website and select “Add Search Engine”, or go to Settings > Search > Add (below the search shortcuts table) to manually enter a search URL.

Firefox Extensions: [Customize your toolbar][1] with the option to remove the extensions shortcut, giving you more control over your browser. When the button is hidden, you can access the extensions panel again at any time from the Firefox menu by clicking the Extensions menu item.


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/customize-firefox-controls-buttons-and-toolbars

You can now [unload tabs][1] by right-clicking on a tab (or multiple selected tabs) and selecting "Unload Tab". This can speed up performance by reducing Firefox's memory and CPU usage.


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/unload-tabs-reduce-memory-usage-firefox

[Full-Page Translations][1] now prioritizes translating only the content near your current view, improving speed and responsiveness. Content outside your view is skipped unless you scroll to it, reducing unnecessary resource usage.


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/website-translation#w_translate-the-full-page

Firefox builds in Arabic now come with a built-in Arabic dictionary for the [Firefox spellchecker][1].


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/how-do-i-use-firefox-spell-checker

[Address autofill][1] enabled for users in Italy, Poland, and Austria.


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatically-fill-your-address-web-forms

The Pocket toolbar icon, as well as the Pocket integrations on New Tab, have been removed per the [service shutdown announcement][1].


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/mozilla/building-whats-next/

Added platform support for [aria-keyshortcuts][1] in Linux, macOS, and Windows.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Attributes/aria-keyshortcuts

Added support for the [CookieStore API][1], an asynchronous cookie API for scripts running in HTML documents and service workers.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/CookieStore

Added support for the [Custom Highlight API][1], which allows styling arbitrary text ranges. Support for [text-decoration][2] is not included and is planned for an upcoming release.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/CSS_Custom_Highlight_API
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/text-decoration

Added support for the [pointerrawupdate][1] event. This event provides lower-latency access to pointer movements by firing as soon as the pointer data is available, typically before the main `pointermove` event. Unlike `pointermove`, it performs an additional hit test to determine the target and fires more frequently, which may impact performance even if only a listener is added. This event is intended for applications that require high-precision input handling and cannot achieve smooth interaction using coalesced `pointermove` events alone.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Element/pointerrawupdate_event

Service Workers are now available in Private Browsing Mode. This enhancement builds on our efforts to support IndexedDB and the DOM Cache API in Private Browsing through encrypted storage. With this change, more websites, especially those that rely on background tasks, will be able to benefit from Service workers.

Firefox now applies a [uniform user agent (UA) style][1] to `<h1>` elements, regardless of whether they are used inside `<article>`, `<aside>`, `<nav>`, or `<section>`. 


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Elements/Heading_Elements#specifying_a_uniform_font_size_for_h1
Firefox will now escape less-than (`<`) and greater-than (`>`) symbols when serializing HTML attributes, making certain mXSS attacks on websites more difficult.

Improved the search feature in the Inspector panel to help developers more effectively search the DOM of the current page. Sorting the results by the number of matching elements, support “pseudo” selector state, etc.

You can find information about policy updates and enterprise specific bug fixes in the [Firefox for Enterprise 140 Release Notes][1].


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/firefox-enterprise-140-release-notes

Various [security][1] fixes.


  [1]: https://www.mozilla.org/security/advisories/mfsa2025-51

With the release of Firefox 140, we are pleased to welcome the developers who contributed their first code change to Firefox in this release, 18 of whom were brand new volunteers! system_requirements:
## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 10 or later

### Recommended Hardware
-  1 gigahertz (GHz) or faster compatible processor or System on a Chip (SoC)
-  1GB of RAM / 2GB of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  500MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.15 or later

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 or Apple silicon processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - glibc 2.17 or higher (glibc 2.28 or higher on arm64)
    - GTK+ 3.14 or higher
    - libglib 2.42 or higher
    - libstdc++ 4.8.1 or higher (libstdc++ 6.0 or higher on arm64)
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - PulseAudio
